Chapter 7, Part 2: Distinguishing the Noble Ones. Thus far, the two gates of entering cultivation have been explained. Through these two gates, the mind attains concentration.
Having attained mental concentration, what else should one cultivate?
Verse:
Relying on the accomplished stillness, one cultivates the foundations of mindfulness for insight,
Observing body, feelings, mind, and dharmas with their specific and general characteristics.
The wisdom of intrinsic nature and hearing, etc., the other characteristics and objects,
Are said to arise in sequence, and there are only four to counteract delusions.
Discussion:

Having already cultivated and accomplished stillness as the basis, one cultivates the four foundations of mindfulness for insight to be quickly accomplished, because one who has not attained concentration cannot see things as they really are.
How does one cultivate the four foundations of mindfulness?
By observing body, feelings, mind, and dharmas with their specific and general characteristics.

That is, the practitioner focuses his mind on a single object and observes separately each of the objects such as the body, etc., by means of their specific and common characteristics, and cultivates the four foundations of mindfulness.
Distinguishing the meaning of the difference between this dharma and the remaining dharmas is called observing the specific characteristics.
Distinguishing the meaning of the non-difference between this dharma and the remaining dharmas is called observing the common characteristics.
As for the foundation of mindfulness of the body observing the specific characteristics, it means observing the specific characteristics of the various parts of the body.
Observing the common characteristics means observing that all the parts are the same in being the characteristics of the body, the same in being the characteristics of form.
Or, observing the specific characteristics means observing the individual characteristics of the body.
Observing the common characteristics means observing that the body is impermanent, etc., like the other conditioned things.
The foundations of mindfulness of feeling, etc., should be understood in the same way.
These four each have three kinds, such as their intrinsic natures, etc. The intrinsic natures are wisdom and the three of hearing, etc.
The mixed refers to the dharmas that exist together with these three.
The objects refer to the objects of these three kinds of wisdom.
Why are these three all called foundations of mindfulness?

Mindfulness causes wisdom to obtain stability on its object, because mindfulness and wisdom assist each other in the excellent samÄdhi, etc. Therefore, the name â€œmindfulnessâ€ is established for wisdom. It is also called â€œmindfulnessâ€ because it is mixed with the object.
Why is it said that there are three kinds of mindfulness?
It is said that there are three kinds for the three kinds of sentient beings, who are confused about the aspects, equipment, and objects.
Or, there are three kinds because of the three differences of faculties, resolve, and stage.
Among the three, that which is mixed is able to eliminate the passions, and the other two are not able to eliminate them, because they are too weak or excessive.
However, the term â€œmixedâ€ also includes the substance of wisdom, because wisdom and its associates are mutually mixed.
If it is said to be the essence, it should not depend on anything. In order to show that it depends on something, the term â€œmixedâ€ is used.

It is included in the mindfulness of dharmas that is cultivated by means of practice, because eliminating the passions must be in samÄdhi. Because it can eliminate the passions, it takes the four or five aggregates as objects. Because it can eliminate the passions, it takes nirvÄá¹‡a as an object.

The attention directed to the common characteristics of the four foundations of mindfulness can eliminate the passions, but the attention directed to the specific characteristics of the four foundations of mindfulness can only eliminate the passions, because it has only a small part of the object in common.
The first three of the four foundations of mindfulness have only unmixed objects, but the fourth has both mixed and unmixed objects.

However, the knowledge of the three truths has only mixed objects and can eliminate the passions. The knowledge of the truth of cessation, although it has only unmixed objects, can also eliminate the passions.
The foundations of mindfulness of body, etc., are each of three kinds, because there are differences in the internal, external, and both internal and external.

Of the three kinds of foundations of mindfulness of body, that which has as its object the continuity of ones own body is called internal, that which has as its object the bodies, etc., of others is called external, and that which has as its object both is called internal and external.
One who has self love and is lax should contemplate the internal body as if it were external.

Or, the internal is as explained above, that which has as its object the non appropriated is called external, and that which has as its object the continuity of others is called internal and external, because it acquires the two names of non appropriated and of ones own body.
Or, it has as its objects the sense bases, the objects, and both, and is called the three.
Or, it takes as object sentient beings and insentient things, and both together, and is distinguished into three.
Or, it takes as object sentient beings, external insentient things, and hair, etc., and is distinguished into three.
Because they all arise from the internal body and exist apart from the faculties, they are given both names.

Or, it takes as object sentient beings in the present as internal, and insentient things in the three times as external. It takes as object sentient beings in the past as internal and external, because they are a class of sentient beings and fall into the category of dharmas.

Moreover, in the future they will fall into the category of sentient beings and correctly fall into the category of dharmas. In the past, they once fell into the category of sentient beings and correctly fell into the category of dharmas. Those dharmas that are unarisen are of the class of the arisen,
and the three kinds of feeling, each with three, should be explained according to the previous principle as appropriate.
These four foundations of mindfulness are said to arise in sequence.
Why is the order of arising like this?
The order of arising is like this because the characteristics are mutually supportive.
Because sentient beings are for the most part attached to the enjoyment of form, they do not attain the superior Dharma.
What is the cause of this attachment to the enjoyment of form?
It is because of deep attachment to feeling. This attachment to feeling is due to an undisciplined mind, and the undisciplined mind is due to the passions.
The mind can be disciplined by faith and so on. One contemplates these principles and the four foundations of mindfulness arise.
Or they arise in accordance with the coarseness or subtlety of the objects.
However, this is not because the mind, in the final contemplation of dharmas, is extremely subtle because of nirvÄá¹‡a.
When one contemplates feeling in the same way as one contemplates form, one can understand its characteristics by analogy, because they arise together with the mind and share the same fate.
Other masters say:

Form can be aggregated and dispersed, can be grasped and abandoned, and its continuity is similar. Impurity, suffering, etc., are easy to understand, and craving, etc., are generated in the body in most cases. Men and women generate craving in each other.
The three contemplations of impurity, mindfulness of breathing, and discernment of the elements are all gateways to cultivation that take the body as their object in most cases.

When cultivating the foundations of mindfulness, one should first contemplate this, because this contemplation gives rise to the touch of lightness and comfort, and the touch of lightness and comfort leads to the arising of pleasant feeling, because a sÅ«tra says that when the body is at ease, one experiences pleasure.
In this way, pleasant feeling arises in dependence on the mind, and pure mind as a cause leads to the attainment of the fruit of liberation.
For this reason, feeling, etc., are contemplated in sequence, and thus the foundations of mindfulness arise in this order.
These four foundations of mindfulness are neither more nor less, because they can cure the four inversions of purity, etc.
Contemplating the body as impure cures the inversion of regarding the impure as pure.
Although the inversion of regarding the impure as pure is common to all five aggregates, still, merely contemplating the body's own nature as impure is able to completely subdue it.
Just as a person who has already contemplated the impure nature of excrement also does not delight in what arises from excrement,
in the same way, having already contemplated the impure nature of the body, one also does not delight in what arises from the body.
Therefore, those who contemplate the body as impure do not delight in the five aggregates of clinging.
Those who are deluded by the notion of purity in the conditioned body delight in what arises based on the body.
Therefore, those who contemplate the body as impure do not delight in what arises from the body.
Just as when one abides in the contemplation of impurity, although one does not directly contemplate sound, etc., as objects, one discards singing, etc., as if it were excrement.

In the same way, when one abides in the mindfulness of the body, although one does not directly contemplate feelings, etc., as objects, because one contemplates the body itself as impure, one never delights in the three objects such as feelings, etc.

Moreover, although one does not contemplate the form and formless realms as impure, one does not fail to generate the aspect of non-delight towards those objects. Therefore, although the notion of purity takes the five aggregates as its object, when the mindfulness of the body is accomplished, it is able to subdue them all in general.
The last three types of mindfulness should be contemplated in the same way, and one should consider how the principle of subduing in general is accomplished.
Contemplating that feelings are suffering cures the error of considering suffering to be pleasure.
That is, if a dharma is truly desirable, it is called pleasure.
Seeing a superior quality that is desirable in a practice mixed with many faults is called the error of considering suffering to be pleasure.

This error must be preceded by indulgence in feelings, because after deeply indulging in feelings, one falsely generates the idea of pleasure in all contaminated practices that serve as the basis for affliction.
Therefore, when one contemplates that feelings have the nature of suffering, one is then able to subdue in general the error of considering suffering to be pleasure.
Contemplating that the mind is impermanent cures the error of considering the impermanent to be permanent.

That is, because the practitioner detests and despises feelings, he sees that the mind that serves as their basis has many different kinds of distinctions. He then draws forth the contemplation of impermanence and makes it present. He then does not generate the idea of permanence with regard to the conditioned, and therefore he is able to subdue in general the error of considering the impermanent to be permanent.

Contemplating that dharmas are not self can cure the delusion of self with regard to what is not self. This means that a certain type of person hears that self is impermanent and does not rejoice in his heart. He then thinks:
Who causes this mind to have many distinctions?
That is my self.

In order to block this idea, one should contemplate carefully and exclude the three and the rest, which are only dharmas. One then does not give rise to the idea of self with regard to anything. Therefore, one is able to completely subdue the delusion of self.
Or, in order to counteract the four foods of morsel food, contact, consciousness, and volition, the four foundations of mindfulness of body, etc., are established in sequence.
The number of foundations of mindfulness is only four, neither more nor less.

In this way, having already cultivated the two preparatory practices of contemplation of impurity and mindfulness of breathing, one is able to gradually induce the foundations of mindfulness of body, feeling, mind, and dharmas, which are not mixed with objects. Next, one induces the foundation of mindfulness of dharmas that is mixed with objects, and then one should cultivate the foundation of mindfulness of dharmas that takes the general characteristics of dharmas as its object.
What are the characteristics of this foundation of mindfulness of dharmas?
Verse:
They dwell in the mindfulness of dharmas, generally observing the four objects,
Cultivating the aspects of impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and non-self.
The treatise says:

The miscellaneous mindfulness of dharmas has four kinds in total, distinguished by taking the four, three, two, or one aggregate as its object. Only the one that generally takes the five aggregates as its object is cultivated here.
They dwell in this and cultivate the four aspects, generally observing all body, feeling, mind, and dharmas, namely impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and non-self.
However, when cultivating this mindfulness, there are other wholesome roots that can serve as the preparatory practice. They should be cultivated in sequence and made to appear.

That is to say, when they have already thoroughly cultivated the miscellaneous mindfulness of dharmas and are about to cultivate this mindfulness, they should first generally cultivate the aspect of non-self, next observe arising and ceasing, and next observe dependent origination.

This is because when practitioners first observe the arising and ceasing of conditioned phenomena from causes, it is easy for them to enter the gate of observing the connection between cause and effect.

Some hold that one first contemplates conditioned arising, then subsequently arouses the contemplation of the three meanings of conditioned arising. This contemplation is immediately followed by the cultivation of the seven good factors. Because one becomes skilled in the seven good factors, one is able to establish the truths of cause and effect in the previously seen realms and contemplate them in sequence.

Having thus thoroughly cultivated wisdom and concentration, one is then able to establish the truths in accordance with the successive contemplations, namely, the suffering, etc., of the desire realm and upper realms, each separately. In this way, one contemplates the sixteen aspects in the eight truths in sequence, cultivating what has not been cultivated.

By means of the wisdom of hearing, one first arouses this sixteenfold contemplation of the eight truths, like seeing various forms through a thin silk cloth. This is called the completion of the wisdom of hearing.
The wisdom accomplished by thinking should be explained in the same way.
Next, one deeply feels disgust for saá¹ƒsÄra and delights in the tranquil virtues of nirvÄá¹‡a. After this, one often brings the contemplation of disgust to the fore.
Gradually increasing and gradually surpassing, it gives rise to such supreme wholesome roots that are conducive to penetrating insight and are included in the category of contemplation.
Immediately after cultivating this total contemplation of the common characteristics of dharmas, what wholesome roots are born?
Verse:
From this, the dharma of heat is born, fully contemplating the four noble truths,
Cultivating the sixteen aspects, next the peak is born in the same way.
Thus these two wholesome roots, all first with dharmas and later with four,
Next, acceptance only contemplates dharmas, the lower and middle grades are the same as the peak,
The upper only contemplates the suffering of desire, one aspect in one instant,
The supreme worldly dharmas are also like this, all with wisdom, excluding attainment.
Treatise:

After the supreme contemplation that is conducive to penetrating insight and is included in the category of contemplation, the first wholesome root that is born through cultivation is called the dharma of heat. It is a distinction of the total contemplation of the common characteristics of dharmas.

The good roots that are produced are to be cultivated, and they are the sign of the fire of the holy path that will burn the fuel of the passions, just as the first sign of smoke appears when one is drilling for fire. The good roots are called the dharma of heat because they are the same as heat.

Because the period of time during which these good roots are produced is long, one is able to investigate the objects of the four noble truths, and for this reason one cultivates the sixteen aspects of the truths.
One contemplates the noble truth of suffering and cultivates four aspects of it: impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and nonself.
One contemplates the noble truth of the cause of suffering and cultivates four aspects of it: cause, accumulation, production, and condition.
One contemplates the noble truth of the cessation of suffering and cultivates four aspects of it: cessation, quiescence, excellence, and separation.
One contemplates the noble truth of the path and cultivates four aspects of it: path, suchness, practice, and exit.
The differences in these aspects will be discussed later.

However, although the dharmas of heat take the four truths as objects, they are said to be associated with the practice of disgust for the most part, because at the time they are produced, the idea of the aggregates is predominant.

When the practitioner cultivates and practices this heat good root, the upper, middle, and lower grades gradually increase and progress, and in the Buddha's teachings on suffering, accumulation, cessation, and the path, they give rise to compliant faith and contemplate that all existences are constantly being burned by a raging fire.
Faith is foremost among the Three Jewels.

The next good root that arises after the cultivation-perfected part of the factors conducive to penetration is called the peak teaching, which is a distinction of the mindfulness of dharmas that generally takes the common characteristics.
The term peak indicates that this is the most excellent place, just as when auspicious events reach the time of accomplishment, the world says that this person has reached the peak.
That is to say, among the four good roots included in the form realm, two are movable and two are immovable.
Among the movable two, the lower one is called heat;
The upper one is called peak, because it is the highest among the movable ones.
Among the immovable two, the lower one is called patience, because it is extremely patient with regard to the objects of the four truths;
The upper one is called the supreme worldly dharma, because it is the most excellent in the world, just like ghee.
The Abhidharma-mahÄvibhÄá¹£Ä-Å›Ästra says:
The characteristics of cultivating these wholesome factors reach the peak, so they are called the peak factors.
The objects and aspects of this are the same as the heat factors, referring to contemplating the objects of the four truths and cultivating the sixteen aspects.
Thus, the two kinds of wholesome roots of heat and peak, when first being established, only have the mindfulness of dharmas, and later, in the stage of progress, all four are present.
The phrase first being established shows that with the aspects one first treads the traces of the four noble truths.
The phrase later progress shows that from this point onward, the lower, middle, and upper levels are gradually cultivated.
The previously attained are not present in front, because one does not give rise to a reverent mind towards them.
Because these wholesome roots are drawn out by superior applied practices, one does not give rise to reverence in the already attained.
However, although these peak factors take the four truths as objects, the faith in the Three Jewels mostly manifests.

The roots of good of the summit stage, in the lower, middle, and upper stages, gradually increase and grow until they reach fulfillment. Then there arises a superior root of good of the class of preparation for penetrating insight called the faculty of patience. It is a variety of the application of mindfulness to dharmas that generally takes dharmas as its object. It is called patience because it is the most superior of the patiences that are able to tolerate the four truths.
Also, this stage of patience is called patience because it does not retrogress and fall.

Even though the supreme factors conducive to penetration tolerate the four noble truths, they do not retrogress and fall, because they are able to enter the path of insight without delay. However, they do not completely contemplate the principle of the four noble truths.
This patience completely contemplates the four noble truths and therefore is given the name of patience. Therefore it is said that it is called patience that conforms to the truth.
This patience, whether it is the stage of added effort or the stage of refinement, is the application of mindfulness to dharmas.

It is different from the previous patience. It is called patience that conforms to the truth because it is gradually similar to the path of insight, because the path of insight is only the application of mindfulness to dharmas.

However, this patience has three levels, weak, medium, and strong. The two levels of weak and medium are the same as the summit of the cycle of dharma, that is, one is able to observe the four noble truths as objects and is able to cultivate the sixteen aspects of the truths.
The strong level is different, for it only observes the suffering of the realm of desire, because it is adjacent to the supreme worldly dharmas.

On the basis of this interpretation, it is established that the roots of good such as heat are all able to take as objects the suffering, etc., of the three realms, etc., because there is no distinction.
How are the weak, medium, and strong of patience distinguished?

Patience of the weak level has eight kinds of mind. That is, the spiritual practitioner observes the suffering of the realm of desire with four aspects and calls it one kind of mind. In this way, he observes the suffering of the realms of form and of non-form, and he also observes the truths of origination, cessation, and the path in the same way, completing eight kinds of mind, called the weak level of patience.

In the middle forbearance, the aspects and objects are reduced and abbreviated. This means that the practitioner contemplates the suffering of the desire realm with four aspects, up to fully contemplating the path of the desire realm with four aspects. In the upper realms, one reduces one aspect of the path. From this point on, it is called the beginning of the middle forbearance.

In this way, the aspects and objects are gradually reduced and abbreviated, up to only contemplating the suffering of the desire realm with two minds, like the stage of the receptivity to the knowledge of dharmas with regard to suffering and the knowledge of dharmas with regard to suffering. This is called the completion of the middle forbearance.
The upper forbearance only contemplates the truth of suffering in the desire realm, cultivates one aspect, and is only one instant, because this wholesome root arises and does not continue.
Immediately after the upper forbearance, there is the accomplishment of cultivation, which first opens the door to the holy path and is supreme among worldly merits.

This is the distinction of the application of mindfulness to dharmas that generally takes common characteristics as its object, included in the stage of equipment, and the supreme wholesome roots that arise. This is called the supreme worldly dharmas.
Because it is impure, it is called mundane. Because it is the most excellent, it is called the highest.
Because it is the most excellent, it is called the highest worldly dharmas.
This is like the above acceptance, taking the desire realm's truth of suffering as its object, cultivating one aspect, and lasting only one moment.

In this way, reducing the aspects and objects in this way, in this way, gradually approaching the view of the truth, therefore the highest worldly dharmas only take the suffering of the desire realm as their object, cultivating one aspect, lasting only one moment, because they immediately enter the state of separation from birth. In this state, there is definitely no principle of continuity.

However, there are nine wholesome roots bound to the form realm. The lowest of the low, the low of the low, the middle of the low, and the high of the low are called heat. The low of the middle, the middle of the middle, and the high of the middle are called summits. The high of the high and the middle of the high are called acceptance. The high of the high is called the highest worldly dharmas.
What is the essence of the four dharmas such as heat?
The essence of heat, etc., is all wisdom by nature. If they are accompanied by auxiliaries, they are all included in the five aggregates, because the associated form must exist.
However, it is not the case that they obtain it, because it is not the case that the wholesome roots of heat, etc., of the noble ones appear again.

However, it is not admitted that those who have already seen the truths cause heat, etc., to appear again, because it would be useless for those who have seen the truths to cause the appearance of the added efforts.

In this matter, when the dharmas of heat are first established, one cultivates one of the four foundations of mindfulness in the present and four in the future, according to which of the three truths one takes as an object. One cultivates one aspect in the present and four in the future, and one cultivates only the homogeneous, not the heterogeneous.

When the foundation of mindfulness of dharmas with regard to the truth of cessation is present, one cultivates one in the present and four in the future, and when one aspect is present, one cultivates four in the future. It is not the case that one who initially contemplates the cessation of the aggregates is able to cultivate the path that takes the aggregates as an object.

In the subsequent stage of progress, when one cultivates one of the four foundations of mindfulness with regard to any of the three truths as an object, one cultivates four in the present and four in the future. When one aspect is present, one cultivates sixteen in the future.

When the foundation of mindfulness of dharmas with regard to the truth of cessation is present, one cultivates four in the present and sixteen in the future. When one aspect is present, one cultivates sixteen in the future.
In the first stage of abiding, one only cultivates the same type, because one has not yet attained this kind of spiritual lineage, and because one's practice in the truths has not yet been extensive.
In the later stage of increase, it is the opposite, and therefore one is able to cultivate the same and different types.

In the first stage of abiding of the summit, in relation to any truth among the four truths, the present cultivation of the future four is the present cultivation of the future sixteen aspects of the mindfulness of dharmas.

In the later stage of increase, in relation to any truth among the three truths, the present cultivation of the future four is the present cultivation of the future sixteen aspects of any one of the four establishments of mindfulness.
In relation to the truth of cessation, the present cultivation of the future four is the present cultivation of the future sixteen aspects of the mindfulness of dharmas.

In the first stage of abiding and the later stage of increase of the receptivities, in relation to any truth among the four truths, the present cultivation of the future four is the present cultivation of the future sixteen aspects of the mindfulness of dharmas in relation to any one of the four aspects.
This is said in general terms based on the class of receptivities.
The Abhidharma-koÅ›a states, â€œWhen one cultivates the four foundations of mindfulness in a general way, one cultivates the sixteen aspects in a general way.â€

This means that when one cultivates the four foundations of mindfulness in a general way, one cultivates the sixteen aspects in a general way. If one cultivates three, two, or one foundation of mindfulness, one cultivates twelve, eight, or four aspects respectively.

The supreme worldly dharmas, taking the suffering of the desire realm as their object, cultivate the four foundations of mindfulness in the present and future, and cultivate one aspect in the present and four aspects in the future.
One only cultivates the same class, not taking other truths as objects. Therefore, one only cultivates those aspects.
Other masters say:
Because they are close to the path of seeing and resemble the path of seeing, one only cultivates those aspects.
This means that the dharma perseverance for suffering only takes the suffering of the desire realm as its object and cultivates four aspects, and the supreme worldly dharmas are also like this.
We have already distinguished the characteristics and essence of the wholesome roots that are produced. Next, we should distinguish their meanings.
The verse says:
These are the aids to penetration, all of which are accomplished through cultivation,
In six stages, two or seven, based on the body of the desire realm, nine,
The third obtains two, male and female, the fourth female is also like this.
The noble ones abandon it by losing the stage, ordinary beings by death.
The first two are also abandoned by regression. Relying on the basis, one necessarily sees the truth.
After abandoning, one obtains what was not previously obtained. The two abandonments are by nature non-obtainment.
The treatise says:

These four excellent roots of goodness, namely heat, summit, patience, and supreme worldly dharmas, are called the factors conducive to penetration. They are divided into four kinds according to lower, middle, upper, and upper-upper, as previously explained.
Decisive means decisive, discrimination means discernment.
Decisive discrimination refers to the noble path, because the noble path can eliminate doubt and can discern the characteristics of the four truths.
Factors means segments, which is the path of seeing, because it is included as a part of decisive discrimination.

Heat, etc., as conditions, attract the factors conducive to penetration, because they benefit them. Therefore, they are called conducive to penetration.ğŸ”½Therefore, this is called conducive to penetration.
These four kinds are all acquired by cultivation, not by listening or contemplation, because they are far removed from the stage of discernment.
These four roots of good are all based on six stages, namely, the four meditations, the stage of preliminary concentration, and the intermediate meditation.
They do not exist in the realm of desire, because there is no samÄdhi there.
They also do not exist in the higher stages, because they are associates of the path of insight.

Also, because the mind of the formless realm does not take the realm of desire as an object, one must first completely know and eliminate the realm of desire, because it is the coarsest of the three realms.

These four roots of good are able to attract the retribution of the five aggregates of the realm of form as a cause for perfection, but they are not able to attract the same class of existence, because they are extremely disgusted with all existence and yearn for perfect quiescence.
Or, the word â€œorâ€ indicates that there are two different opinions, namely, that the two, heat and summit,
The Venerable Sthavira says:
They are based on the previous six and the seven stages of desire.
The Abhidharma masters do not accept this explanation, because they are not acquired by listening or contemplation, because they are the factors that are conducive to penetration.

These four roots of good are produced in bodies in the realm of desire, in the nine places of rebirth of humans and celestials, excluding the northern continent Uttarakuru. They are only produced in the nine bodies of desire, because it is possible to enter into separation from desire.

The other three roots of good are first produced in the three continents, and later, being born in heavenly places, they continue to be present. The exception is also first produced in heavenly places.
Other masters say:
If one has previously cultivated the four preparatory stages, they are all first produced in heavenly places.

These four roots of good are only in male and female bodies. The first three are both obtained by males and females. The fourth is also obtained in a female body, because one must not obtain a male body later and not form heat, etc.
In dependence on a male body, one only obtains the good roots of a male body, because a saint who has gone to another rebirth does not become a female.
The states of heat, summit, and patience may have a change of physical state. Therefore the two are good roots that are causes for each other and for abiding.

When the supreme worldly dharmas are supported on a female body, they can be the cause of two results. This is because a female who has obtained the holy paths may later transform and obtain a male body.
When they are supported on a male body, they are only the cause of one result, because one who has obtained a female body has already obtained the nonanalytical cessation of a female body.
When a holy one obtains these roots of good by depending on a stage, he loses them when he loses that stage.
The phrase â€œloses the stageâ€ means that he moves and is born in a higher stage.

When an ordinary person loses or does not lose a stage, he definitely loses these roots of good when he loses his class affiliation. This is because the roots of good are nourished by the power of the path of insight of the holy one.
These four roots of good are not lost through death.
How do we know that death causes loss only for ordinary beings and not for holy ones?
Because the Abhidharma-Å›Ästra says that ordinary beings in the egg and the womb only possess the body and do not possess bodily action.

Isnâ€™t it the case that ordinary beings first generate the dharmas of heat, etc., by depending on lower stages, and later, when they are born in a higher stage, they definitely lose the roots of good such as heat?
There is no such error, because at that time, the ordinary being loses the roots of good because he loses his class affiliation.
That is, when one is in the state of death, if one is not provided with the holy path, one loses the roots of good by the arising of the intermediate existence of a higher stage.

If holy beings are in the state of death and are provided with the holy path, they do not lose the warmth, etc., but they do lose the good roots of lower stages by the arising of the intermediate existence of a higher stage. Although the time of loss is the same, the causes are different. Therefore, ordinary beings do not lose the roots of good by changing stages, but holy beings definitely do not lose them by death.

Although ordinary beings lose the forbearance of suffering when they die, they definitely do not fall into evil destinies and are born in evil destinies, because they are not subject to discrimination.

Because the body is once the abode of the forbearance of suffering, the passions and actions that can be attracted to evil destinies no longer operate in the body, just as various beasts do not enter the abode of a lion.
The first two roots of good are also lost through regression. Such regression and loss is possible for ordinary beings, not for holy ones.

The last two are not lost by regression by ordinary beings or by holy ones. When the roots of good such as warmth are produced in dependence on the fundamental meditations, one definitely realizes the holy truths in this life.
Because their faculties are sharp and their disgust with existence is deep.
Those who rely on the preliminary and intermediate stages to give rise to heat and so on may not necessarily enter the path of insight in this life.
